original_title: Sri Lanka to introduce hotline for reporting harassment
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT –A dedicated hotline through which victims can report harassment of women and children would be introduced, Minister of Public Security Tiran Alles said.
“I have told the acting IGP that we would introduce a three-digit hotline like 119 to report harassment faced by women and children,” Alles said at a press briefing on Tuesday (19).

According to a survey done by the department of census and statistics, 24.9 percent of women in Sri Lanka experienced physical or sexual violence, and 28.9 percent of women who were victims of violence sustained an injury.

Another minister last week highlighted a study that showed a majority of femicides in Sri Lanka were perpetrated by male family members or close associates, and that the police was usually sympathetic toward the perpetrator and not the victim.

“The government is working on a new law to reform the domestic violence act, reform of marriage and divorce laws to ensure there is an easier path to divorce: no one should be forced to remain in a marriage that is either abusive or not healthy,” Jeevan Thondaman, Minister of Water Supply and Estate Infrastructure Development said in parliament earlier this month.

The government plans to bring in an Online Safety Bill, which it says will tackle online crime to protect children and women from negative impacts of the internet like pornography and harassment.
However the proposed law has alarmed many due to its many grey areas and lack of proper definitions. (Colombo/Dec20/2023)
